name: wrought
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
made or done in a careful or decorative way: The new album contains some carefully wrought new songs and a number of familiar hits. Her poems are well-wrought and intensely personal. Synonym
shaped
More examplesFewer examplesOhlson's beautifully wrought book is firmly centred in the inner city of Cleveland, Ohio.The same is true of "Aguacero", a finely wrought painting by Marcelo Pombo.I enjoy a cunningly wrought visual gag as much as the next person.

not standard (only as a past participle and in the past tense) caused (something to happen): A recurring theme is the environmental change wrought by a slowly warming planet. She says the new visa rules wrought havoc at the local consulate.
More examplesFewer examplesOn Boxing Day, a tsunami wrought havoc across South Asia.The changes he wrought go far beyond two massive election victories.Seeing the damage wrought in his home county gave him a sense of what it must have been like for New York officials to witness the destruction in lower Manhattan.

past simple and past participle of wreak
wrought adjective [not gradable]
(MADE)
brought into being; made: She’s modest about what she has wrought.
